Fields.DialogueText: Porazitel'nyy tragedii! Oh, nzhc trageddiii!
First Comrade Kirov, look, I think we all have some appreciation for your... vocal talents, but could you at least pick a song that's a bit less, dour?
Oh, but Kapitan, do you not hear the shrill shriek of a minor key that's hung over my life like a black cloud?
What? Oh dear...
Are you not a sufferer of the human condition? Do you not feel the same winter sting as me?

Fields.MenuText: To be honest, Kirov, I have no idea what the hell you're talking about. Are you drunk?
I committed myself to confronting the ugliness that is war a long time ago. But there's no use in letting it anchor you down.
Wait a minute, Comrade, I thought you were a Leningrad girl?! One tough woman? And now, I find you moaning on the deck?

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, Kapitan! I'm forced to see the brutal world as it is, and my eyes and ears burn with the sting.
Kapitan, don't you know that there are conditions that make war feel like a holiday? I suppose you're right, but it's hard to say that now.
Bah! Don't make me laugh, Kapitan. What you say is true. Soviets, we've all got a big weakness.
Well are you going to just sit here and belt out Russian tragedy pieces, speaking in cryptic puzzles, or are you going to tell me what's going on?
The atrocity is almost too much to speak. My dry lips can't bear it.
Kirov, if something happened, you must report it to me, you know? What's going on here? I'm serious. Spit it out, Kirov!
Kapitan, it's... it's...
*ALARM*
Damn! There's the alarm. Save it, Kirov! We've got Morganas to deal with. This better not be as serious as you're making it out to be.
@BATTLE
Interesting position out here topside, Comrade. Do you plan on wallowing over the deck-boards all day, or actually getting up and making yourself useful at some point?
I'm in the clutches of grief, Kapitan. The heart stricken down to a slow slumping thump.
What happened to the Leningrad work ethic?
Oh, that. Please, Kapitan, we both know all the house chores are done already.
Well I can't help you if you never tell me what's going on, Kirov.
Oh, it's a true mystery, how my heart can be so brave in battle, and so weak for embarrassment. You'll just laugh at me, Kapitan. I can't burden you with my issues.

Fields.MenuText: I won't laugh, I promise. Why don't you just try and talk about it?
Come on, Kirov, I think we both know that human misery is the ultimate cause of laughter. If you want to talk, I'm here.
Fine, enjoy your melancholy by yourself. Just quit rolling around like a slug on the deck. This is a military vessel.

Fields.DialogueText: Girls don't like liars, you know? How can you promise not to laugh?
Spasibo, Kapitan. Spoken like a true friend. I'm just not sure that conversation is the best cure this time around.
Ha! Trying to motivate me with a little tough love, is that it? Who knows, Kapitan? I might just be the kind of girl motivated by a little... push.
Hmm... Mind telling me what you're gripping so tightly?
It's nothing, Kapitan. Really, it's nothing. Who's keeping an eye out for the Rusalkis, eh?
It's supposed to be you, but, wait a minute... do I smell brandy?
The very last of it, Kapitan! The final bottle of brandy. If you put your nose up to the top, you can still smell the flavor!
Kapitan! Your presence is requested on the bridge. We have Morgana ships approaching.
@BATTLE
You have got to be kidding me, Comrade Kirov! Is this really what this whole tragedy has been about?
Kapitan! See, I told you that you would just end up laughing. Laughing at my torment.
Oh, come on Kirov, drop the tragedy act. Surely, it can't be so bad to give your liver a break. Jump back up on the wagon.
A wagon that races down a rocky road of jutting bumps.
Your body will thank you, you know.
Maybe you forgot, Kapitan, but I'm a spirit manifested... I don't have a body!
Someone's a little cranky. Forgive me, but you must admit you can look a lot like a human, and you complain as much as one too.
Don't you know there's no worse time to mess with a Leningrad girl than when she runs out of alcohol, especially brandy?

Fields.MenuText: Kirov, I know this may seem tough right now, but give it a little time. This may even turn out to be a good thing.
Well moping around and being down about it isn't going to do any good. Sing a song, read some Marx, scout for Rusalki... just do something other than bitch!
What happened to a Leningrad girl being resourceful? We both know you were well over-dipping into the alcohol rations anyway.

Fields.DialogueText: A good thing, Kapitan? Leningrad women are practically born with the bottle in their bobber. At least respect the loss.
Do something other than bitch?! Is that really what you want, Kapitan? Fine then! How about I throw you overboard?!
So I may have over-dipped a little bit, Kapitan. So, what?! How many times have I saved our asses? The struggles of the sea take a cold toll.
Kirov, Morganas approaching from astern. Come on, get up.
Please, Kapitan, as if I'm going to fall for a trick that easy.
First Comrade! I'm not joking. Come on, before they start firing. Get into position, people!
@BATTLE
Perhaps you're right, Kapitan. Maybe there is a little glimmer of hope at the end of this whole abstinence period.
Now that's something I never thought I'd hear you say.
One of my sisters never had a drink, you know?
There's some inspiration for you! I'm sure that it worked out well for her.
She nearly killed a sea-trader aboard her boat. With a fork. She's the crazy one.
This doesn't speak well for the direction of modern medicine.
Kapitan! We've got a radio call from Command. They want you. It's urgent.
Wait, Kapitan, surely you don't have to go yet? How urgent can something really be?
What's gotten into you, Comrade?
Oh, it's nothing.

Fields.MenuText: Why are you suddenly so afraid of being left alone? Pick yourself up.
I'll try to come back quickly. In the meantime, why don't you try singing a song or something?
Sorry to leave you alone with your issues, Kirov, but I have real problems to take care of.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan, I've been up. I've been up for so long now.
Hey, Kapitan! Now that's an idea. When has there ever been a better time for the healing power of music?
Girls like a bit of teasing, Kapitan, but there's a fine line. Don't be a mudak!
Wait, Kapitan! I wouldn't go to that radio room just yet, if I were you.
Honestly, Kirov? Are you trying to threaten me now?
No, but those Rusalki ships out there look threatening.
@BATTLE
Moya sladkaya lyubov', where did you go...
What a truly uplifting melody, Kirov.
Are you teasing me, Kapitan?
Be careful of letting the crew hear that, or they're likely to dive over the rails into the ocean with a smile!
You're the one who suggested a song, remember?
True, and I also remember using the words positive, uplifiting, inspirational, life is a beautiful struggle...
Ugh, don't make me hurl, Kapitan.
No, Comrade Kirov, you're right. I won't make you any sicker. I've got just the thing to make you better though.
They're going to send more drink rations?!
Nonsense, Kirov. Why would they do that at a time like now? Command has a special operation for us. Something to get you up, and thinking about other things!
It better not be some fluff you dreamed up, Kapitan. This spirit needs the movement and emotion of a great Stravinsky piece.

Fields.MenuText: No, definitely not, Comrade. Ha! I wouldn't dream of trying to pull one over on you like that.
It's hard to say just what kind of danger we might encounter, but the brief does make you wonder.
Prepare to dive into the depths of heart-throbbing naval danger. We might not make it through this one, Kirov.

Fields.DialogueText: You're a terrible liar, Kapitan. Do you even know the details of this yet? Distracting, da, but I'm not so sure this is making me feel better.
I see. Are you always this non-committal when you talk with women? I can't help but admit, the mystery does intrigue me.
Tah! Please, Kapitan, you think I'm foolish enough to fall for something like that? Now you're just making things up!
All right then, Kapitan, why don't you tell me the details of the mission?
Right after we deal with this fleet of Morganas, Kirov. Prepare yourself!
@BATTLE
Kapitan, I didn't realize you were the type to always keep women waiting. We get impatient, you know?
I hate to break it to you, but we're a long way off from the next ration shipment.
I wasn't talking about brandy, Kapitan.
Forgive my assumption and the look of utter shock on my face. What is it you're waiting on?
I swear your memory is worse than a Soviet bureaucrat, Kapitan... The exciting news that you swore would lift my ailing spirits? Remember?
Of course! How could I have forgotten?
Could be something to do with your thick and stubborn skull?
Astute observation, Comrade. Noted. Now as far as the actual details of the mission, we don't have much. A couple of merchant ships have been attacked, just south of here.
Great... So we're off trying to defend weak cargo ships again, is that it?

Fields.MenuText: It's hard to say what we're going to be tasked with, but this isn't one to write off.  Who knows the danger that may wait for us?
It may not be hunting down the fiercest Morganas in the sea, but at least it's something to keep us busy until our war efforts are recalculated.
I hear that skeptical and unenthused tone of yours, Comrade, and I'm not impressed. Treat every objective with your full effort and commitment.

Fields.DialogueText: Perhaps I've been at sea too long, but this whole thing just sounds like some second rate pirates who got bored, likely to crash their overloaded boat before we even get to them.
Right! Of course! Of all the ways I want to spend my day, investigating the wreckage of some random merchant ships is ranking at the very top!
Spoken like a true kapitan! Your fierce determination is nothing short of inspiring! I'd be lying if I didn't admit that I want my lover to have the same qualities in the bedroom...
But surely, Kapitan, those cuff-linked colonels in Command must have had more to say on the matter? Don't tell me we're in going brandy-less and blind!
Step one is to find the wreckage and investigate. We may be steaming into an unknown situation, Comrade, but that's hardly any reason to sail without authority.
Merchant ships, eh? Makes you wonder what they may have been selling.
*ALARM*
A wonder you may have to sit on for a while. There's the alarm! Prepare yourself, Kirov.
Rusalki dogs, prepare to face the wrath of a sober Soviet woman!
@BATTLE
Kapitan! Are you going to spill the news, or just stand there with that twisted-lemon face that's got me so concerned?
What are you talking about, Kirov?
Kapitan! Kapitan! Please, coming from the radio room, huffing and puffing, with that sideways smirk glued to your sweet-cheeky mug?
Sweet cheeky-mug...
Do you really think you can keep secrets from me?

Fields.MenuText: Part of being a captain is knowing what information needs to stay confidential, Kirov. How do you know I'm not already keeping secrets?
Keep secrets from you, First Comrade Kirov? I wouldn't dream of it!
I thought you might have a little fun trying to figure out just what details I might be hiding.

Fields.DialogueText: You sneaky bastard, Kapitan! I suppose I don't know everything, but the gleam in those sweet, innocent eyes makes me think your sleeves are not so empty.
Oh, Kapitan, those are the very remarks which leave the most doubt. You may have fooled other girls in the past, but my eyes can stare right through any secrets!
Oh, most of the fun ran out when the brandy did. Must I really interrogate you?
You've caught me. Command has informed me of heavy Morgana sightings just south of here.
Great tragedies, Kapitan. En route to the wreckage site?
On that very route. So strap in, Kirov. We may be going up against some real danger.
Well we certainly won't have to look far to find it...
What do you mean, Kirov?
Look starboard, Kapitan! Rusalki dogs have returned already!
@BATTLE
Kapitan, you're sure that these are the correct coordinates?
Exactly what Command sent me. Keep your eyes peeled, Kirov. The wreckage site must be close by.
Well, at least we solved one mystery! I know where the rest of the alcohol rations have gone.
What are you talking about, Kirov?
The boys in Command must be sloshed off their asses! What are these coordinates?! I haven't seen a Rusalki or sign of a merchant ship anywhere around here.

Fields.MenuText: You have to be patient, First Comrade. Just because we haven't spotted a threat doesn't mean it's not there.
Bah! Perhaps those bastards really are drunk. It's a ghost ocean out here.
You should be happy we haven't run into a Rusalki ship yet! I plan to stay alive, and each battle limits our chances of that, you know?

Fields.DialogueText: Sometimes, Kapitan, you sound like a seasoned and wise sailor! I'll keep an eye out, though it hardly seems sharp without a lick of brandy to sharpen the image.
See, Kapitan?! Those overdressed bureaucrats are so far from the actual they wouldn't know a wreckage site if they sailed right into it!
Kapitan, your words are worse than an off-tone soprano! I thought you were a captain of the sea? A figure of command, and fearlessness. You should be embracing battle.
No use in complaining about what Command may have gotten right or not. These are the coordinates they gave us to work with, and somebody has to investigate.
Well maybe somebody should tell them to quit investigating the inside of their own assess!
Please, Kirov, have some decency.
How can you ask me to have decency at a time like this, Comrade?
A time when we are out of alcohol?
Well, yes... but also when there are so many Rusalkis nearby.
What?!
Portside, Kapitan. Perhaps you're the one who needs to pull the head from their ass.
@BATTLE
And it seems the coast is clear yet again.
Too clear, Kapitan. I'm beginning to think this merchant is something Command just made up to torture me in my time of mourning.
Time of mourning?
My good friend Brandy, Comrade... She's left me.

Fields.MenuText: Get a hold of yourself! You still have friends, food, the air to breathe, and a place to hide from the wind and rain. I think all that opera is going to your head.
I know it's not easy, Kirov, but perhaps it's time to stop mourning the loss - and time to start looking forward to the future, to blue skies.
Come on now, Kirov! It may seem bad now, but I'm sure your old gal-pal will be back. Plenty of Rusalkis left to destroy to help cheer you up, too.

Fields.DialogueText: Of course it's gone to my head, Kapitan! I was born with the opera in my bolts. But as much as it pains me to admit it, maybe it is time to move on...
Look forward to the future, Kapitan? How can I look forward to the future with this splitting headache!
Of course, she'll be back, Kapitan. She wouldn't leave me for good. Do you think she would? Kirov, stop! You've got to use that Leningrad heart now!
Oh no... Dear Lord, help me.
Don't tell me you're still bellyaching over your accumulated hangover.
Worse than that, Kapitan. I think I've made a mistake.
This could clearly go one of two ways. Might as well just come out with it now, Comrade.
Damn! Kapitan, no time. The Rusalkis have found their way back to us.
@BATTLE
All right then, Kirov. Out with it. Tell me what happened.
Please, Comrade, tell me you have a sliver of forgiveness in that rigid heart of yours?
Rigid heart?

Fields.MenuText: Be truthful, and I can make an accurate judgment. You want me to be honest, right?
If you haven't noticed, Kirov, I run a pretty tight ship around here. One wrong move can cause a lot of heartache.
Kirov, my heart is big enough to have you snuggle right inside of it! Of course, a sliver of forgiveness can fit in their too.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, howI want that, Kapitan... but if I'm being honest, sometimes I want my lovers to lie to me. *wink* I guess I'm not really sure what I want yet.
It goes both ways, Kapitan - but if you can't forgive me, then you may never know what I'm talking about.
Bah! Kapitan, you can be so hokey sometimes. You've brought a summer flush through my winter cheeks though, stupid joke or not...
Remember when we chased down that pack of Rusalki street dogs?
You mean Morganas. Right. How could I forget?
And then you said to keep an eye on coordinates...
For god's sake, Comrade.
I think... I've figured out why we haven't found the wreckage site yet.
*ALARM*
No time to reminisce on your recent discovery, Kirov. The Morganas have found their way back to us, so let's get our guns up.
@BATTLE
You... you got us LOST, Kirov?!
Hold on just a second here, Kapitan! It's not like I'm the only one to blame.
Really? Forgive me for having to step to the turrets.
My sweet Kapitan! Do not break my heart! Besides, we're not lost... just blown slightly off course.
Slightly, Kirov?
Nizghtttttt, Traggddie! Give me a little slack, will you? My brain isn't working the same lately. I'm adjusting to this strange new way of thinking.
You mean sobriety?
That's such a harsh word, Kapitan.

Fields.MenuText: Harsh, maybe, but a word you should familiarize yourself with nonetheless.
I suppose it does have kind of a dour ring to it. Take as much time as you need, Kirov.
Comrade Kirov, why would you even need brandy when you have someone like me around?

Fields.DialogueText: Blah, blah, blaaaaaaaah! Spare me the life coaching, Kapitan. Us Leningrad girls know what's good and bad.
That's just the thing though, Kapitan. It's like I've got too much time on my hands. The clock's hand is moving in this slow, painful slicing motion.
Oh, Kapitan! Your presence is indeed intoxicating... but some days, I'm really not sure, you know?
So just forgive me if I seem a little crazy as of late. It almost feels like I'm seeing things at times.
Now you really are starting to sound crazy.
Like those bottles floating out there in the water. I must be hallucinating them.
No, Kirov, those are real! And holy smokes, there's a lot of them.
Empty bottles, floating all around... WHAT KIND OF CRUEL WORLD IS THIS?!
Solve that mystery later. Right now we've got unwanted guests. Prepare to fire!
@BATTLE
Ow, my head...
The navigator won't confess, so tell me. Be honest, Kirov, how far off course are we?
Are you really sure you want me to be honest with you, Kapitan? Is an honest woman what you truly desire?

Fields.MenuText: Do I need to repeat myself?
No use sugarcoating things, First Comrade.
Maybe not. Don't tell me.

Fields.DialogueText: I don't know, Kapitan, that authoritative tone does kind of rile me up, if you know what I mean?
Especially if you're used to the flavor of warm vodka... and bitter brandy... That smoky, robust, bold...
Not you! I thought you were the true kapitan of this ship. Would you really hide from problems?
Kapitan, if I'm being as honest as the Soviet government, we're not far off at all. Right around the sea-bend!
And if you're not being as honest as the Soviet government?
We're up shit river, Kapitan. Far off course.
Great. I guess that's what we get for going after the Morganas instead of sticking to the mission.
Oh, Kapitan, don't be so hard on yourself.
I should be hard on you instead?
Ha! I'm much too sober for that, Kapitan.
Ah! Look alive, Kapitan. Do you see that?
The bottles?
Come on, Comrade, no! Those Rusalki shit-dogs out there on the horizon.
Good eyes, Comrade. Prepare for battle!
@BATTLE
All right, Kirov, that's enough. I think you're drooling on your shoulder stripes.
All right, Kirov, tell me you've redeemed yourself. What have you been able to pull from those maps?
Look, Kapitan, I may have made a mistake, but you're talking to Leningrad's finest here. I know how to read a map.
Well then?
According to the coordinates, Kapitan, we should be right on track as long as we follow the direction of these floating bottles.
Right, that sounds overly-promising.
Don't think I can't hear that sarcastic tone, Kapitan! You charming smartass. Do you really not trust me to get us towards the wreckage site?

Fields.MenuText: I put you in charge of the charts, didn't I?
Of course I trust you, Comrade Kirov. Just don't disappoint me this time.
I don't really have a lot of other people to turn to, do I?

Fields.DialogueText: There's that rugged tone again, Kapitan. Oh! When you talk like that, you sound, you sound like Leningrad's finest sailor.
Kapitan, I'm known for a lot of things, but disappointment has never been one of them.
There's a fine line between teasing and being a genuine asshole, Kapitan. I'm not sure you understand the difference.
Kapitan, look! Out there in the water...
Alcoholic delusions again, Comrade?
How do all ship kapitans become so damned stubborn? No, my dear, the giant planks of metal out there.
Son of a bitch, Comrade, good eyes. Looks like we might not be so far from the wreckage site, after all.
Ahem, What was that you just said, Kapitan? I didn't quite hear you. Can you repeat yourself?
No time, Kirov. Morganas off the bow. Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
You were saying something about my eyes, and how beautiful they are. Please continue.
It's like we're swimming in a sea of glass out here.
But every bottle seems cracked and devoid of any alcohol. Zhestokiy mir!
That's probably a good thing. Otherwise you'd jump over the rail and into the drink.
I wouldn't mind jumping into a drink. Maybe two. But come on, my dear, give me more credit than that!
It does make you wonder what was in those bottles though.
One can only dream of the pleasures they held. What do you think might have been in those bottles?

Fields.MenuText: How on earth am I supposed to know?!
They were obviously filled with the finest pomace brandy available!
Slim chance they actually contained alcohol, Comrade. They were probably filled with fuel or milk... or something.

Fields.DialogueText: Lighten up, Kapitan. I'm only trying to have a little fun. I may come off cold, but all girls like a little fun in their lives, you know?
Oh, Kapitan! It's as if you're speaking the language of love. I'm salivating! Tell me more! Whisper it in my ear...
How dare you ruin my hopes and dreams, Kapitan?! Don't you know you ought to let a girl dream?
Keep your eyes peeled, Comrade. I'm seeing more wreckage floating our way.
This smoky haze lingering...
See that? Some ships on the horizon. Maybe the remains of the merchant ships?
If you want me to look through the binoculars, Kapitan, all you have to do is ask, you know? In fact, if you asked nicely, you might find me willing to--
Not now, Kirov! Tell me what you see.
Wreckage. Something twisted and ruined.
Are those the ships?
Nope, those are Rusalki ships. Come on, Kapitan. You should know better!
Damn it! Every time. Sound the alarm!
@BATTLE
Morganas have led us astray in the past, but this time they've led us right to the wreckage site.
You can practically smell the arson in the air.
Now that you mention it, there is a peculiar smell in the air. It almost smells like, like...
Alcohol, Kapitan. That's the smell of sweet, sweet fermentation!
By god, you're right, Kirov! It actually smells like a barrel of burning gin... but what happened here? We've got nothing but bits of burnt metal.
Something seems familiar about these large chunks of debris. I just can't put my finger on it.
Should we call an investigation team out here, to see what they can make of it?
And wait around until the people of Leningrad have money in their pockets? We both know it would take Command ages to send a team like that, Kapitan.
I suppose you're right.
You're the ship kapitan! Isn't there anything we can do to find out what happened here?

Fields.MenuText: Let's spend a little more time surveying the area. Perhaps there's something out here, but we just haven't found it yet.
We could try throwing a fishing net out. We might be able to pull in some debris and get a clue.
Sounds crazy, but maybe sending a team out in a dinghy would allow us to get eyes closer to the wreckage and find a clue.

Fields.DialogueText: Surveying the area? Maybe you ought to stop surveying the inside of your ass. Think for a moment! If we haven't seen anything yet, we're unlikely to find anything now.
You have my full support, Comrade. There's nothing more rugged and handsome than watching a sailor pull in a heavy fishing net!
Don't tell me you were the one who drank all my brandy, Kapitan! Send my people out in dinghies?
Kapitan, you're a character of... many ideas, but I'd concur with casting a fishing net to retrieve flotsam.
Seems you're finally making yourself useful around here, Kirov. Good suggestion. Glad I came up with the idea.
Hey! Watch that mouth of yours, Kapitan, or I'm likely to throw you out with the net!
Looks like the only things we'll be throwing out are torpedoes. Morganas off our port side. Prepare yourself!
@BATTLE
What about my mouth?
Maybe I want to kiss it... or perhaps I want to throw something at it. I have not decided.
Sladkiy obratnyy khoddddd!
What's this? A surprisingly chipper sounding tune? Kirov, I wholeheartedly approve.
Bah! Perhaps it's time to change songs then.
Spare me the attitude. I only meant that it's nice to see you...
It's almost as if you've been briefed in the art of Soviet compliments, Comrade. It pains me to admit it, but I am feeling a bit more... spirited lately.
Spirited?
As though a gust of wind rippled with sweet arpeggios through my sails!

Fields.MenuText: Must be all this time you're spending with me. We should do this more often, you know.
Maybe it has something to do with having a couple of sober moments for the first time in who knows how long?
I've been under the impression that your entire life is a tragedy, Kirov, so I must say that seeing you like this is a pleasant surprise.

Fields.DialogueText: Kapitan! Is that honestly what you think? Who knew the bold character that you can actually be?
My dearest comrade, girls don't like to have their faults addressed, you know? I figured a kapitan would have learned how to behave like a gentleman already.
Oh Kapitan, what is life but a series of highs and lows? We Leningrad people have long been burdened by an extra helping of tragedy and suffering. It's a Soviet thing, Comrade.
Enough small talk, Kapitan. I tire of you trying to make a move at me. I can only resist your advances for so long!
I beg your pardon?
Tell me, did you pull anything up with the fishing net?
As a matter of fact, Kirov, we did!
Don't make me wait around all day! Spill the sauce!
I won't make you wait around any longer, but they might. Morganas off the bow!
@BATTLE
I was going to say, "to see you not wallowing in despair."
Oh? Nice to see me? Gaze at my beauty then, should it please you. I know it pleases you. You cannot deny that I am--
Kapitan! How dare you wait until now to show this to me?
We kept getting interrupted. Either it was Morgana attacks... or your constant outbursts.
Oh, Kapitan, I do hope you think of my qualities as endearments! We Leningrad women can be a strange breed.
And impossible to decipher sometimes. Anyway, speaking of deciphering, can you read the script on that metal sheet? We also pulled in this bottle.
Of course I can read it, my sweet! This is Soviet language. The state has been trying to wipe out illiteracy, you know?
All right then, Kirov. Let's see if you can pull off something that's worthy of reporting to Command.
The Cyrillic letters intrigue me, Kapitan, but I still don't see what this whole goose chase has to do with us.

Fields.MenuText: Goose chase? Kirov, there was obviously big weaponry discharged in this area.
These were the orders from Command, like it or not.
Would you rather be stagnating at sea, whittling away the time while you wait for orders to come down the pipeline?

Fields.DialogueText: Ok Kapitan, maybe this is worth looking into. The way you've phrased it has got me unexpectedly excited.
Oh, Kapitan, I love it when you're forceful with me like that. Don't worry, my sweet, I'm along for the ride no matter what.
Perhaps you might stagnate and... and whittle who knows what, but I always have the aria and the opera to occupy my thoughts!
Well then, Kirov, how about it? Can you read anything?
Ahhhh... We may have a lot more trouble on our hands that we thought.
Sounds promising, but check our starboard side, Kirov. Our Morgana friends decided now would be the perfect time to get in the way!
@BATTLE
Oh, and should I mention what else occupies my thoughts when I look at you, Kapitan?
Tell me, Kirov, are you rehearsing for the theatre, or is that the face that you always make when you've been thinking too hard?
Kapitan, I've examined both the bottle and the metal siding you recovered.
And?
Well, the good news is, there's some good news. But the bad news is, well, there's bad news.
Would you quit stalling?! You know you could have just said there's good and bad news.
For some reason I get the most distinct pleasure from putting you in suspense. I know it's a little sick, but I just can't help myself.

Fields.MenuText: Are you kidding me, Kirov? We run a tight schedule here, and if anything goes awry, there are lives on the line! I don't have time for these school-girl games.
I know it's hard because I'm such an attractive person, but we can't allow ourselves to get distracted from the matter at hand.
I shouldn't encourage you... but I can't help but admit a tingle through my spine at your words.

Fields.DialogueText: I hear you, Kapitan! No need to be upset. Like it or not, I simply don't know how to act any other way.
Ha! I don't think we'll have to worry about any distractions on my end. No one is going to be able to see around that giant head of yours anyway!
Keep it together, Kapitan! I'm flattered, honestly, but don't fire the turrets off yet.
All right then, enough small talk. Break the news to me.
Do you want the good news first, or the bad news?
Kirov, for god's sake, just tell me what kind of information you got! Who knocked off this merchant ship?
Rusalkis! The alarm, Comrade.
Of course...
@BATTLE
A thrill, Kapitan, to know you look so closely at my faces! Then again, with my features, who could blame you?
Out with it, Kirov. Hurry and debrief me before another Morgana decides to drop in on us.
Debrief you? Oh! Right away, Kapitan! I feel like singing to commemorate our joy! Smertttti! Nyet, Nishda...
KIROV! The information from the wreckage. Please.
Huh! Forgive me, Kapitan. I thought you were referring to... something else.
Kirov...
Bad news first, then. This piece of metal came from a Soviet ship, not a typical merchant ship.
That's strange...

Fields.MenuText: Maybe the merchants fought back?
It's possible that the merchant ship was the aggressor, but attacking while disguised as a warship.
It won't be so hard to find the attacker. Just look for a ship with a metal sheet blown off the side.

Fields.DialogueText: Highly unlikely, with so many bottles floating around. Why would they attack while carrying so much merchandise... delicious merchandise...
Bah! You make a much better captain than detective, you know? One of these ships was carrying a lot of bottles. This was clearly a heist.
Aha! Brilliant thinking, my cherished commander. Sometimes you really do act like a kapitan.
This red and black seal, and the letters here? Kronstadt. This designates a ship of the Red Sailors.
You act as if I should know who that is.
They may come from a small cold island off Leningrad, but they are one tainted political faction you do not want to butt heads with.
Ah sounds, great. And the good news?
Actually, Kapitan, looks like more bad news has found us first. Rusalkis, at the bow.
@BATTLE
And now for the good news, Kapitan.
About time. We could use a boost to lift our spirits about now.
This bottle? Premium, tip of the very top Russian brandy. Most people in Leningrad wouldn't even dream of getting a hold of a bottle like this.
Is that so? Perhaps we've discovered quite a treasure here.
If those other empty bottles we saw floating were of the same label, then this boat was carrying some pricey, and incredibly delicious, devil-drink.
Good chance of it. Seems like we've figured what the merchant was carrying, anyway.
Do you know what this means, Comrade?! Bog ulybayetsya.

Fields.MenuText: Don't get any ideas. We can't hunt thieves, then commit the same crime ourselves. I run a ship of principle, Kirov.
My heart sings! We're chasing a hoard of delicious brandy that's begging for you and me to come and save it!
We still don't know the situation... but if we do come across liquor loot, we might report a couple of bottles short...

Fields.DialogueText: I hear you loud and clear... but can't you just let a girl dream sometimes?
Da! Say that again! Sing it to the heavens! Oh, Kapitan, I could kiss you! Still, just like being in bed, we don't want to get overly excited too soon.
Kapitan, I love the way you think! A couple of short bottles that maybe I could share with you? Mmm, I love this idea!
A lot of this is exciting, but still speculation. Now tell me, Kirov, what about these Red Sailors?
Captain! Morgana ships are approaching from the port beam.
Rusalki dogs want to go again? Come hither, you nasty things!
@BATTLE
You're awfully lucky, you know that, Kapitan?

Fields.MenuText: Lady Luck can be a sweet mistress, First Comrade Kirov. Especially during wartime. I'm grateful to have her around.
To live in the middle of a war? You have quite an optimistic outlook, Kirov.
For having a charming Leningrad girl such as yourself around? Is that lucky... or is it a curse? Give me a kiss to remind me.

Fields.DialogueText: But what about me, Kapitan? Is Lady Luck really the only mystical apparition who's going to get some love and recognition here?! I see where I stand with you. Hmph.
Soviet optimism, Kapitan. You acknowledge the shit storm, and then ride right through the middle of it while desperately clinging to a painful grin. See?
What can I say, Kapitan, I'm a song-wielding magic girl! Oh, I love it when you flirt with me.
Well, what is it then? Tell me you've got something good.
I've always got something good, Kapitan. Not everyone gets it though. *wink*
Kirov!
Forgive me. I'm only teasing. The real good news is that the Red Sailors are based out of Kronstadt!
Ugh... How is that good news?
Kapitan! It's right off the coast of Leningrad. I could easily surmise their preferred routes, from all of my time spent nearby.
Kirov, you dirty dog!
Hey! Come on, Kapitan, you're talking to a lady.
Does this mean?
Da, Kapitan. I think I know where these thieving renegades might have gone.
*ALARM*
Seems like we've got some business to take care of first. There's the alarm!
@BATTLE
What's the score then, Comrade? Where are we likely to find these thieving dissenters?
Istinnyy severrrrr, Kapitan. True north. I'd bet my last bottle of brandy on it.
You don't have any more brandy, Comrade Kirov.
A tragic truth, Kapitan, but the odds that some will come into my life soon have risen dramatically!
You've got a one track mind, Kirov.
A two track mind is more accurate.
What's the second tra... You know what? Never mind. We've got bigger things to worry about.
Bah! Seems like that's the defining theme of our time together.

Fields.MenuText: Kirov, you're smiling. Maybe you're having a lot of fun without brandy, but you're scared to admit it.
Command at sea in wartime is a challenge, Kirov. I'm grateful for your humor to help me through it all.
But things are about to change, Comrade Kirov. After we deal with these Red Sailor bastards, we'll be sailing calm seas!

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, my dearest Kapitan, I'll always have fun, liquor or no. I'll admit though, it's been nice having you around to lighten my mood.
Is there really any better way to look at life, but with a humorous attitude? Swing through enough operas, and you'll find yourself laughing at the tragedies.
Calm seas, Kapitan? Did you forget that we are at war, and that Rusalkis are stalking the seas? Who would want to sail on peaceful waters anyway, sounds boring.
Then it's settled. North it is. We start our hunt after these Red Sailors.
You might want to wait before ordering that course, Kapitan.
Damn. Don't tell me your rudder is jammed.
My tail wiggles just fine, Kapitan... see? But our Rusalki friends have come back to pay us another visit though.
Son of a bitch. Why are these waters crawling with so many Morganas? All hands to battle stations!
@BATTLE
All right Comrade, directions set for true north. Now, what kind of distance are we talking about here?
Well as it turns out, Kapitan, we may not have to go far at all.
Excuse me?
That ship over there... Perhaps it is only a speck on the horizon to you, but I can see that she flies the Red Sailor's flag.
You honestly have unbelievable eyesight.
I'm a spirit, Kapitan, so I see things a little bit differently. Also, brandy is good for the eyes.
I'm not sure I've ever heard that before.
Kapitan, you know I adore long conversations, but the ship, and the brandy, we've been looking for is right over there!

Fields.MenuText: Get them on the radio. We'll give them the option of confession and surrender.
One well-placed torpedo up the backside should do the trick.
Let's radio for some reinforcements.

Fields.DialogueText: Radio? Kapitan, I understand doing things by the book, but then you might as well just slap a giant target on our hull and ask if they'd like to shoot us first.
Da, Kapitan! But maybe we should aim for the bow. We don't want to destroy that precious liquid cargo!
Back-up?! Kapitan, how long is that going to take? We don't have time to wait around for more of these ships to show up. I need a captain who can make moves.
Shit, Kapitan! They're firing at us already.
Wait... That's not gunfire from the Red Sailors. We've got Morganas in the mix!
@BATTLE
Time to fight them off! We can't have Rusalki stealing our stolen brandy before we can steal it for ourselves!
Damn it! The brandy bandits evaded us. How unsporting, so slink away when the Rusalki wenches arrived on the scene.
And it looks like they've called in some more friends, too.
Smart and sneaky boys, these Red Sailors. I should not be surprised, I suppose. They're practically Leningrad people.
We'll catch up with them soon. Did they jettison any of that cargo?
Kapitan, I took a look through the binoculars and counted crates upon crates of bottles on board. Not a single crate went overboard.

Fields.MenuText: You realize we're here to fight Morganas and suppress piracy, right? Not just to get drunk?
Good eyes, Comrade Kirov. I can almost taste that brandy!
Let's worry about surviving before worrying about those bottles. Morganas are swarming out here.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, Kapitan, don't remind me. It's a tragedy that Shostakovich is unworthy of composing about... yet I will accept it, so long as it means spending more time with you.
My precious and beloved kapitan should know that if a single bottle had fallen, I would have them pulling at the oars of a dinghy to fetch it!
I hear you, Kapitan, and I wholeheartedly agree. I also refuse to go down until I recover at least one of the stolen items!
Kapitan, there is one other thing I wanted to say...
Comrade Kirov?
Well this whole adventure we've been on, this opera we've been writing together, it's...
Well, it truly stirs the heart of this Leningrad girl, being alongside her Kapitan through it all! Why, if she were not so sober, this same girl might even admit that--
*ALARM*
I want to hear it, Kirov, but...
@BATTLE
Again the Morganas interrupt us?!At a moment when my heart was nearly so nearly open that a Soviet tank could fit through?!
A tragedy, Kapitan! Such a tale of woe will never be outdone! Could you imagine a story more full of tears and sadness?
You're sad because the Red Sailors' pirate ship was destroyed? I do feel a bit guilty, now that you mention it.
Guilty? How can guilt crease the brow of my lovely Kapitan? Our guns did not destroy that ship full of golden, miraculous brandy. The wasteful Rusalki destroyed them!
I know that our guns didn't sink the Red Sailor ship--
Correct! I would never risk those crates of brandy!
But we did endanger them, all the same. We chased the Red Sailors of Kronstadt. The Morganas chased us. Our pursuit led the Morganas to the Red Sailors.
Pfft... logic. Ah, but different tales often have the same endings, Kapitan. Try Russian literature, and you will see it clearly.
Right! Silly, forgetful me, Kapitan. This adventure we've woven together? This is tale of bravado and danger. Tell me truly, Kapitan... is it also a tale of attraction and love?
First Comrade...
Does your heart throb for me with the same melodic desire that mine does for you?

Fields.MenuText: I don't think I could put it in better words, Comrade Kirov. Yes, my heart beats the same.
Kirov, are you confessing what I think you're confessing? Of course I feel the same way about you! How could anyone who's spent time with you feel any different?
First Comrade Kirov, I value you deeply as a true friend... but we both know that being a ship's captain demands certain restraint.

Fields.DialogueText: I would have at least expected you could try to put it in other words. Come on, Kapitan, you should know by now that I'm a sucker for romance.
Oh, Kapitan, it's a miracle you think that way! I can tell the future is going to be promising with you, Comrade. Embrace me! *kiss*
And my heart croons with tragedy at the harsh reality...
Kirov, you're one hell of a Leningrad girl.
And our tale is not over yet, Kapitan. We might still find an unbroken bottle or two amidst this flotsam...
And I'm indulging your search as long as I can. We know we won't have long until the Morgana reinforcements arrive.
@BATTLE
That final battle churned the bloody waters again, Kapitan. Our chances of finding a drop of brandy have now sunk even lower than the Red Sailors' pirate vessel.
True...
True shame.
Good thing I dragged a net before the battle started.
What?! Did you say "good thing?" Kapitan, you sly dog! Did you find a bottle before the devastation?
What do you say, Comrade? Pop the cork with me?
What took you so long to ask, Kapitan? It would be my absolute pleasure!
It is like this. Once upon a time lived many, many sad characters. The ending comes and... surprise! They are still sad. Sad, or sometimes dead. The end. You see? Always the same.
Then we must not be living in a work of Soviet literature, Kirov. We're alive and well.
So many smashed crates and bottles... Kapitan! I need your eyes down here scanning the wreckage, not looking up at the horizon!
I'm looking at the horizon for a reason, Kirov. And the reason has just arrived. Morganas incoming!
No.
Sigh...
I found two.
TWO?! Two bottles of brandy?! Ecstasy! Oh, Kapitan, those words are a joyous hymn to my soul!
